solution_line_template: First find the total area of the forest: {forest_length} miles * {forest_width} miles = <<{forest_length}*{forest_width}={total_area}>>{total_area} square miles
Then find the total number of trees in that area: {trees_per_square_mile} trees/square mile * {total_area} square miles = <<{trees_per_square_mile}*{total_area}={total_trees}>>{total_trees} trees

Then find the number of trees all the loggers can cut down in one day: {num_loggers} loggers * {trees_per_logger_per_day} trees/logger = <<{num_loggers}*{trees_per_logger_per_day}={trees_cut_per_day_by_all_loggers}>>{trees_cut_per_day_by_all_loggers} trees

Then divide the total number of trees by the number cut down per day to find the number of days it takes to clear the forest: {total_trees} trees / {trees_cut_per_day_by_all_loggers} trees/day = <<{total_trees}/{trees_cut_per_day_by_all_loggers}={days_to_clear_forest}>>{days_to_clear_forest} days

Then divide the time in days by the number of days per month to find the time in months: {days_to_clear_forest} days / {days_per_month} days/month = <<{days_to_clear_forest}/{days_per_month}={months_to_clear_forest}>>{months_to_clear_forest} months
